Autoimmune hemolytic anemia typically shows a positive direct antiglobulin test and is not specifically associated with recent antimalarial treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency typically causes hemolysis during treatment with oxidative stress-inducing medications like primaquine, not after completion of artemether-lumefantrine.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Post-artemisinin delayed hemolytic anemia is a recognized complication of artemisinin-based combination therapy that typically occurs 1–3 weeks after treatment completion. This patient's presentation with hemolytic anemia, spherocytes, and fragmented cells in the absence of parasites is characteristic of this condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Treatment failure typically manifests with recurrent fever and positive blood smears showing malaria parasites.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to fever and confusion. He returned 3 days ago from a 2-month trip to rural Nigeria during which he did not take recommended prophylactic medications or vaccines. His temperature is 40.1°C (104.2°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg. On examination, he is disoriented to time and place. Scleral icterus and splenomegaly are noted. Initial laboratory studies show a hemoglobin of 8.5 g/dL, platelet count of 65,000/μL, and serum glucose of 50 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic study to confirm the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient's presentation with fever, confusion, and hypotension meets the criteria for sepsis, making bacterial infection a key differential diagnosis. Obtaining blood cultures is an appropriate step in the general management of such a patient. However, blood cultures are used to identify bacteria and will be negative for the protozoan parasite that causes malaria. Therefore, this test will not confirm the suspected diagnosis.

B) CORRECT:

The gold standard for confirming the presence and determining the species of Plasmodia is microscopic examination of thick and thin blood smears. The thick smear concentrates erythrocytes, allowing for sensitive detection of parasites, even at low densities. The thin smear provides a monolayer of cells, which is crucial for identifying the specific Plasmodium species and quantifying the parasite density (parasitemia). Species identification is critical because P. falciparum causes the most severe disease and requires aggressive treatment. Quantifying parasitemia helps assess disease severity and monitor the response to therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

A lumbar puncture is indicated in a patient with fever and altered mental status to rule out CNS infections, such as bacterial meningitis or encephalitis. While these are important considerations, this patient's specific travel history, jaundice, splenomegaly, and hematologic abnormalities make cerebral malaria the leading diagnosis. A lumbar puncture would not confirm malaria, but it may be performed to exclude co-infections.

D) INCORRECT:

A complete blood count (CBC) is a necessary part of the initial workup and provides supportive evidence for malaria, such as the anemia and thrombocytopenia seen in this patient. However, these findings are nonspecific and can be present in many other infectious and noninfectious conditions, such as sepsis or dengue fever. A CBC cannot confirm the diagnosis by identifying the causative organism.
questions.hint: This patient's travel history, lack of prophylaxis, and clinical presentation with fever, altered mental status, anemia, and thrombocytopenia are highly suggestive of severe malaria.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of headache, muscle pain, and recurrent fever spikes that occur without a noticeable rhythm. Two weeks ago, he returned from a 5-week-long world trip, during which he climbed several mountains in India, Africa, and Appalachia. Chemoprophylaxis with chloroquine was initiated one week prior to the trip. Physical examination shows jaundice. The spleen is palpated 2 cm below the left costal margin. His hemoglobin concentration is 10 g/dL. A photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear is shown. Which of the following agents is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Trypanosoma cruzi is a parasite endemic to Central and South America. Infection by this parasite causes Chagas disease, which manifests with noncyclical fever, flu-like symptoms, hepatosplenomegaly, and pancytopenia. A peripheral blood smear will show the circulating parasite. Although this patient presents with similar symptoms, his fever pattern, travel regions, and peripheral smear findings are inconsistent with Chagas disease.
Image Description:

Blood smear (Giemsa stain, 100x magnification)

The parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease, can be seen in the center of this blood smear (green overlay). Its characteristic flagellum (yellow overlay) is clearly recognizable.

B) INCORRECT:

Plasmodium ovale is endemic to Sub-Saharan Africa and causes tertian malaria, which manifests following an incubation period of at least 1 week with the symptoms described in this patient. While a peripheral blood smear will show RBC inclusion bodies, the fever pattern in patients with P. ovale is periodic, with spikes every 48 hours. It is also chloroquine-sensitive. This patient, on the other hand, has an irregular fever pattern and an infection that is chloroquine-resistant, making P. ovale an unlikely causal agent.
Image Description:

Malaria is caused by plasmodia transmitted via the saliva of female Anopheles mosquitoes. During development, there is a generational (asexual/sexual reproduction) and host change (between mosquito and human).

Human host
Liver (exoerythrocytic) stage: Following a bite from an infected mosquito, sporozoites (spindle-shaped, infective pathogen) reach the liver via the blood or lymphatic system and mature into schizonts within the hepatocyte. Asexual propagation produces thousands of daughter cells (merozoites), which are transmitted to the bloodstream via merosomes. Plasmodium Vivax and Ovale are associated with the development of dormant stages (hypnozoites) which persist for several years in hepatocytes and later develop into schizonts.

Blood (erythrocytic) stage: Merozoites infect erythrocytes and develop into trophozoites, which then mature into schizonts. Asexual propagation produces merozoites, which are then released into the bloodstream via merosomes. This cycle repeats itself over a course of 48-72 hours causing periodic decay of erythrocytes and the resulting pathognomic spiking fevers of malaria.

Mosquito host
Ingested gametocytes mature into flagellated microgametes (♂) or macrogametes (♀) within the gastrointestinal tract of the mosquito. The mature sexual forms merge into a mobile zygote, which in turn develops into a sporozoite-containing oocyst. The sporozoites are released, enter the salivary glands, and may eventually be transferred to a new host.

C) CORRECT:

Plasmodium falciparum, the causal agent of falciparum malaria, is transmitted by the Anopheles mosquito and is found on all continents except Europe. After an incubation period of at least 1 week, it manifests with the symptoms described in this patient, including irregular fever spikes. Peripheral blood smear demonstrates RBC inclusion bodies, as seen here. P. falciparum is also chloroquine-resistant; a different prophylactic medication (e.g., atovaquone‑proguanil) would, therefore, have been needed to prevent infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Babesia microti is a parasite spread by the Ixodes tick (deer tick), which is endemic to the Northeast and upper Midwest regions of the United States. Babesiosis manifests with a noncyclical fever, flu-like symptoms, hepatosplenomegaly, and anemia. A peripheral blood smear may show RBC inclusion bodies but would more specifically show intra-erythrocyte rings with a maltese cross. Although this patient presents with similar symptoms, his fever pattern and peripheral smear findings are inconsistent with babesiosis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Giemsa stain; very high magnification)

The erythrocyte in the center of this blood smear is infected by the protozoan parasite Babesia microti (green overlay). This obligate intracellular pathogen causes babesiosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Dengue virus is endemic to many tropical and subtropic areas, including India and parts of Africa, and manifests with a noncyclical, high-grade fever, flu-like symptoms, arthralgias, and headache 2–10 days after infection, which is similar to this patient's presentation. However, recurring fever spikes would be unusual, and this patient's peripheral smear findings are inconsistent with dengue fever, which would show elevated lymphocytes and plasmacytoid cells.

F) INCORRECT:

Plasmodium malariae is endemic to Sub-Saharan Africa, Southeast Asia, Indonesia, and parts of South America. It causes quartan malaria, which manifests after an incubation period with symptoms similar to those described in this patient. A peripheral blood smear will also show RBC inclusion bodies. The fever pattern in patients with P. malariae is periodic, with spikes every 72 hours. It is also chloroquine-sensitive. This patient, on the other hand, has an irregular fever pattern and an infection that is chloroquine-resistant, making P. malariae an unlikely causal agent.
Image Description:

Blood smear showing an erythrocyte (red) infected by merozoites of Plasmodium malariae.
In the course of the disease, merozoites may develop into trophozoites (green), which look like ring-shaped inclusions. Trophozoites may then develop into red cell schizonts containing thousands of merozoites, which again may enter and infect yet other erythrocytes.
However, merozoites may also differentiate into gametocytes (male or female). Gametocytes are then ingested when the mosquito feeds to mature within the mosquito's intestine.

G) INCORRECT:

Chikungunya virus is endemic to tropical and subtropical regions such as Sub-Saharan Africa and Southern and Western Asia. Infection manifests with noncyclical, high-grade fever, flu-like symptoms, and arthralgias. Although this patient presents with similar symptoms after travel to an endemic region, his fever pattern and peripheral smear findings are inconsistent with Chikungunya fever.

H) INCORRECT:

Trypanosoma brucei is a parasite endemic to Africa that causes African sleeping sickness, which manifests with noncyclical fever, flu-like symptoms, lymphadenopathy, somnolence, and even coma. A peripheral blood smear will show trypomastigote (the parasite). Although this patient presents with similar symptoms after travel to an endemic region, his fever pattern, lack of lymphadenopathy and somnolence, and peripheral smear findings are not consistent with African sleeping sickness.
Image Description:

Blood smear (Giemsa stain)

Extracellular trypanosomes (Trypanosoma brucei) are visible with a typical streamlined and tapered shape and a flagellum that arises from the basal body.

I) INCORRECT:

Leishmania donovani is endemic to tropical and temperate regions. Leishmaniasis manifests with noncyclical fever, flu-like symptoms, hepatosplenomegaly, and pancytopenia. A peripheral blood smear will show macrophages containing amastigotes. Although this patient presents with similar symptoms after travel, his fever pattern and peripheral smear findings are not consistent with leishmaniasis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a bone marrow tissue specimen (Giemsa stain, very high magnification)

Dark purple, intracellular Leishmania parasites (examples indicated by arrowheads) are visible within a histiocyte (blue overlay).

This finding suggests visceral leishmaniosis. However, the diagnosis should be confirmed by PCR or serology.

N: neutrophil; M: myeloid precursor cell; Eb: erythroblast
questions.hint: This patient presents with flu-like symptoms, irregular fever spikes, splenomegaly, jaundice, anemia, and a peripheral smear demonstrating inclusion bodies following an incubation period presumably of at least 1 week. The most likely cause of this patient's presentation is an infection with an agent that is transmitted by the Anopheles mosquito and is resistant to chloroquine.

questions.text: A 25-year-old volunteer returned from Ghana with three days of intermittent fever, chills, and headache. Laboratory studies show mild thrombocytopenia, an elevated reticulocyte count, and elevated liver enzymes. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Typhoid fever typically presents with a step-ladder fever pattern and gastrointestinal symptoms. The patient's intermittent fever, thrombocytopenia, and features of hemolytic anemia (e.g., reticulocytosis) are inconsistent with typhoid fever.

B) INCORRECT:

Dengue fever manifests with thrombocytopenia and elevated liver enzymes but causes a high sustained fever rather than intermittent fever and is not associated with features of hemolysis (e.g., reticulocytosis).

C) CORRECT:

Malaria is common in travelers returning from sub-Saharan Africa, particularly due to Plasmodium falciparum. This condition causes intermittent fever, chills, and features of hemolytic anemia (e.g., reticulocytosis) due to the synchronous rupture of red blood cells during the parasite's life cycle. Other nonspecific findings include thrombocytopenia and elevated liver enzymes. Diagnosis involves peripheral blood smears to identify the parasite.

Key learning point: Malaria is a common cause of fever in travelers returning from sub-Saharan Africa.

D) INCORRECT:

Babesiosis, a tick-borne protozoal illness, manifests with fever, features of hemolytic anemia (e.g., reticulocytosis), and certain nonspecific laboratory findings such as thrombocytopenia and elevated liver enzymes. However, this condition is endemic in temperate climate zones (e.g., northeastern and midwestern US), not Sub-Saharan Africa.
